awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Building HPRNet (High-Performance Research Network) for Advancement of Data Intensive Research and Collaboration
awd_abstract_narration:
The sizes of scientific datasets are growing exponentially across all scientific disciplines due to several factors such as improved scientific instrumentation, social media and decreasing costs of storage. To extract real value from these geographically distant datasets, researchers need to have access to these datasets at high speeds which is typically not possible with traditional campus networks. The University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) is building "HPRNet", a high performance research network providing last mile connectivity for over 31 research projects. HPRNet not only improves the ongoing research productivity, but also sets the stage for future innovations and collaborations. UIC is a public university and minority serving institution (MSI) in the heart of Chicago area where HPRNet significantly impacts the research training of underrepresented groups. The project team is working with other NSF and institutionally funded minority training programs on campus to ensure access to HPRNet resources.

For HPRNet's deployment, 13 locations are identified at UIC where 10 to 40 Gigabit uplinks to regional, national and international R&E networks are established. HPRNet builds on the Science DMZ model that works in concert with the current campus research network (CRN) and a special data storage system known as Data Transfer Node (DTN) to deliver high-performance and reliable network paths for data-intensive applications, including high-volume bulk data transfer, remote experiment and/or instrumentation control, cloud computing, data-mining and advanced visualization.

por.por_cntn:
The Advanced Cyberinfrastructure for Education and Research (ACER) group, which is part of the Academic Computing and Communications Center at University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC), expanded the physical footprint of its High-Performance Research Network (HPRNet); the HPRNet research network complements the ubiquitous campus academic network. HPRNet provides UIC research faculty and their students with high-performance and reliable network paths as well as the necessary supporting infrastructure -- Science DMZ, Data Transfer Nodes (DTNs) and Globus/GridFTP -- to facilitate data-intensive applications on campus as well as across the nation and the world. This NSF award made it possible to add 13 research laboratories, located in multiple buildings across UIC's major urban campus, to HPRNet and to provide additional research laboratories with access to the supporting infrastructure via the academic network. Access enables researchers to do high-volume bulk data transfers, experiments on remote instrumentation and/or real-time control of remote instrumentation, cloud computing, data mining and advanced visualization -- thereby advancing research, research training and professional development.

More specifically, this award enabled:

  • Physical installations of network jacks, extending last-mile connectivity between major campus research laboratories, located in several campus buildings, to the HPRNet backbone;
  • Installation of Science DMZ, DTNs and Globus/GridFTP, enabling laboratories to send and receive large scientific data flows from data generators (e.g., computers and instrumentation, such as DNA sequencers) to points of analysis and visualization (e.g., computers and visualization systems), both on and off campus;
  • Installation of network measurement machines at UIC's three major data centers to test performance;
  • Upgrades to UIC's aging network infrastructure in several buildings, which will make it easier to connect additional laboratories in those buildings to HPRNet in the future.

Intellectual Merit: Large-scale data transfers from national and international resources are too often the limiting factor in scientific insight and discovery. This NSF award made it possible to extend UIC's HPRNet campus research network and supporting infrastructure to major laboratories, thereby removing this bottleneck. This CC* infrastructure improves the ability of UIC faculty and students to do research and research training, and sets the stage for future collaborations, grant funding and innovations.

Broader Impacts: UIC is a public university and Minority Serving Institution in the downtown Chicago metropolitan area and HPRNet significantly enhances UIC research training programs that attract and educate undergraduate and graduate minority populations in STEM disciplines, through such programs as the NSF-funded 'Bridge to the Doctorate' program and the campus' Minority Engineering Recruitment and Retention Program. Newly connected research laboratories represent a variety of scientific disciplines, including mechanical engineering, civil engineering, bioengineering, computer science, bioinformatics, environmental sciences, medicine, manufacturing, pharmacy, chemistry, and physics.

  • UIC ACER runs 'perfSONAR' network measurement machines. A test between UIC and NCSA verified good performance in terms of throughput and low packet loss. Previously, UIC did not have the ability to detect problems resulting from big data-flow bottlenecks.
    UIC Advanced Cyberinfrastructure for Education and Research group
